A front yard with bare, weedy beds and faded old mulch gets a full reset with clean edges and fresh hardwood mulch.

## The Problem

The front beds along this home had not been touched in over three years. The old mulch had broken down completely, weeds had taken hold, and the edges had gone soft and indistinct — grass was creeping into the beds from every direction. The overall effect made the house look neglected even though the homeowner kept the lawn mowed regularly.

## The Solution

We started by hand-pulling the worst of the weeds and raking out the old decomposed mulch. Once the beds were clean, we used a steel spade to re-cut crisp, defined edges along the entire frontage — about 80 linear feet of bed line. After edging, we installed fresh natural hardwood mulch at a 3-inch depth throughout both front beds, keeping it pulled back from the base of each shrub to prevent rot.

## The Result

The transformation was dramatic. Clean edges create a strong visual separation between turf and beds, giving the property a well-maintained, intentional look. The fresh mulch ties the whole front together, adds a rich color contrast against the green lawn, and will suppress weeds through the winter. The homeowner said the neighbors immediately noticed the difference.

A full property fall cleanup — leaves cleared from lawn, beds, and gutters — so the yard heads into winter in good shape.

## The Problem

By late November this yard had accumulated a heavy layer of leaves from three large oak trees. The lawn underneath was being smothered, which can cause significant turf damage over winter. The planting beds were completely buried, branches had come down from a recent storm, and the gutters were clogged with debris. The homeowner was managing a new baby and simply had not had time to stay ahead of it.

## The Solution

We worked the property in sections, starting with the lawn. We blew the leaves off the turf into the beds and low spots, then ran multiple passes with a high-powered mower on mulch setting to break down what we could. The remaining leaf volume was raked into piles, bagged, and hauled. Storm branches were cut to manageable lengths, bundled, and set at the curb. Gutters were hand-cleared and flushed with a garden hose. Final pass with a blower to clean hardscapes.

## The Result

The lawn came through with no smothering damage — it will green up properly in spring. All beds are clear, hardscapes are clean, and gutters are flowing. The homeowner now books this service every fall, and we added a spring cleanup to the schedule as well.

Side-yard shrubs that had grown into each other and overtaken the walk were cut back, shaped, and cleaned up in a single visit.

## The Problem

The side beds on this property had not been trimmed in at least two seasons. Several large boxwoods had grown together into one continuous mass, completely obscuring a window and extending over the sidewalk by nearly two feet. Beneath the shrubs, years of leaf debris and dead branches had accumulated, creating a hiding spot for pests and holding moisture against the foundation.

## The Solution

We spent the first hour with hand pruners and loppers, opening up the interior of each shrub and removing all dead wood. Once the structure was cleaned out, we used powered hedge trimmers to shape each shrub individually — rounding the tops and bringing the sides back to a consistent depth. The accumulated debris under and around the shrubs was raked out, bagged, and hauled. We finished by cleaning the sidewalk and driveway.

## The Result

Each shrub now reads as its own defined plant rather than part of one overgrown mass. The walk is clear, the window is unobstructed, and the foundation is visible and properly aired out. Total job time was about four hours. The homeowner had been dreading the project for a year — seeing it finished in an afternoon made a big impression.

A neglected backyard with patchy, weed-choked turf brought back to a lush, uniform lawn through deep cleanup, grading, and a consistent maintenance schedule.

## The Problem

This backyard had been left on its own for the better part of two seasons. Broadleaf weeds had taken over roughly 60% of the turf area, bare patches ran along both fence lines, and a low corner of the yard had become a standing water trap that killed off whatever tried to grow there. The homeowners had young kids and wanted a yard they could actually use — the current state made that impossible.

## The Solution

We started with a thorough mechanical cleanup: removing thatch buildup, hand-pulling the densest weed sections, and scalp-mowing the remaining turf to give new growth a clean start. The low corner required light regrading — we brought in topsoil and reshaped the grade to direct runoff away from the problem area. After grading, we overseeded the bare zones with a regionally appropriate turf blend suited to the Greenville, SC climate. The lawn then entered a bi-weekly maintenance rotation to keep it cut at the right height while the new seed established.

## The Result

Within six weeks the bare patches had filled in and the weeds had been crowded out by healthy, dense turf. The regraded corner dried up completely after the next rain event. The homeowners now have a flat, usable backyard their kids play in every afternoon. This project is a clear example of what consistent, properly executed maintenance can do — no chemicals, no shortcuts, just the right work done in the right order.

Patio Paver Installation & Outdoor Entertaining Space
An unused, sloped backyard corner was transformed into a level paver patio with a built-in outdoor kitchen surround — a complete outdoor entertaining space built from scratch.

## The Problem

The backyard of this Greer property had a sloped, unused corner that the homeowners described as "wasted space." They had been planning an outdoor kitchen for years but had no flat surface to build on, and the existing lawn ran right up to the back of the house with no transition zone. The slope also caused erosion that deposited sediment against the foundation after heavy rains.

## The Solution

The project began with excavation and site leveling — we removed approximately 14 inches of grade across the 400-square-foot installation area to create a flat, properly sloped-for-drainage base. After compacting and installing a crushed stone base layer, we laid 2-inch thick concrete pavers in a running bond pattern. Along the back edge we built a reinforced block structure to serve as the base platform for the outdoor kitchen appliances and countertop, which the homeowners sourced separately. The surrounding lawn was re-edged and re-seeded where the excavation disturbed the turf, and a drainage channel was cut along the retaining edge to manage stormwater.

## The Result

The transformation here is dramatic in a way that photographs struggle to capture — the space went from an unusable slope to a defined, level outdoor room. The patio now hosts the family's grill station, a prep counter, and seating for six. The drainage issue against the foundation is resolved. This is the kind of project that changes how a family uses their property, and it is one of the most satisfying types of work we do.
